webTitle: Sportwatch: Sharks eliminate Tigers, Swifts soar, and more - as it happened

fields.headline: Sportwatch: Sharks eliminate Tigers, Swifts soar, and more - as it happened
fields.standfirst:
• Super Netball: Swifts fly into grand final
  • NRL: Sharks eliminate Tigers; Panthers thrash Knights
fields.trailText: Cronulla won the day’s NRL finals eliminator against Wests, while the Swifts celebrated in Super Netball on a busy day of sport around Australia.
fields.body:
9.20am BST

Summary

So the NRL regular season finishes amid a tumbling of records. Nathan Cleary surpassing Mick Gordon’s record individual points tally in one game for a Panther, notching 34. At one stage one of the great all-time NRL marks looked under threat - Dave Brown’s 45 points for Easts in 1935 - but even the Knights couldn’t capitulate that badly.

For all that it was too little, too late for the Panthers who finish as first loser in 9th on the table, as earlier Paul Gallen’s first career drop-goal ensured, well, helped, Cronulla secure the final top-eight spot, at the expense of Robbie Farah’s Wests Tigers.

In the Super Netball the Sydney Swifts completed their metamorphosis from ugly cygnets to beautiful swans, qualifying for their first ever final. The imposing form of Noeline Taurua’s Sunshine Coast Lightning looms there though, as they look to make it three straight championships.

Huge news overnight from the US Open with the shock upset of Serena Williams by teenage Canadian Bianca Andreescu (and there will of course be the matter of another tennis game later tonight - so stick around for that).

We’ll also have day five of the Fourth Ashes Test from Old Trafford coming up shortly - where my comrade-in-arms the ever-versatile JP Howcroft will be back at the controls there.

Thanks for your company, once again. And that’s Sportwatch!

9.01am BST

Full-time: Penrith 54-10 Newcastle

Goodbye James Maloney, good night Newcastle Knights, and hello - the new era at the Panthers, heralded in some style by the Nathan Cleary show.

They only scored above 30 points once all season - they’ve saved their best til last, Penrith. And it sees them finish an agonizing one point outside the NRL finals. The son Nathan might be buzzing just now, the father Ivan must surely be ruing that fact.

Still, a high note for Panthers fans to go home on. For Knights fans a bitter taste that will last until next March you’d imagine.

Updated at 9.05am BST

8.56am BST

76 min: And with their full complement restored after the sin-bin the Knights have thankfully brought a bit of belated steel back to this contest - almost going in themselves, but for some desperate try-line defence from the Panthers.

A close up of a Newcastle fan in the crowd - oh my. That’s a thousand-yard-stare with the gentle tinklings of Simon & Garfunkel if ever you’ve seen one.

8.50am BST

And they’ve gone past the Cowboys and the Titans for season-long points now, Penrith. 400+ points brought up. What attacking issues!

Remarkable to think though. Up until this bloodbath they’d scored less points than a team that finishes the NRL season with just four wins. Yikes.

8.46am BST

NRL - Try! Penrith 54-10 Newcastle (Cleary)

66 min: They’re already on the bus home, the Knights. But how about this kid! And to think he’s still only 21-years-old. No wonder they signed him on a 57 year contract. What a future.

He’s scored a fourth try, he’s converted a ninth goal - it’s an incredible 34-point-haul for Cleary, and don’t bet for a second that he’s finished there.

8.43am BST

NRL - Try! Penrith 48-10 Newcastle (Burns)

65 min: Stop. The. Fight. This is Monty Python’s Knight out there, taking flesh wound after flesh wound. They’re being torn to shreds, Newcastle. Commiserations for any travelling fans who made the journey down the freeway.

Cleary: 8/8.

8.40am BST

NRL - Try! Penrith 42-10 Newcastle (Cleary)

64 min: There’s a drought across western New South Wales but it is beginning to absolutely rain in Western Sydney. And who else - it’s Cleary with his second career hat-trick of tries!

He kicks the conversion - 7/7. They are coming home HARD, Penrith.

Updated at 8.42am BST

8.38am BST

A bit more on all of that:

I was meant to go to the bathroom and do a bunch of other miscellaneous tasks during the HT break, but I spent the 10-15 minutes break trying to crunch some stats for you (the perils of an idle mind).

Trying to get my head round how Panthers can look reasonably good across the park but then score so few points (only Bulldogs have scored less this season) and musing on the absence of “finishers”.

In the list of top tryscorers across the whole NRL the first Panther enters the list in 33rd position (Brent Naden, with Brian To’o the only other player to enter the top 50). All 15 other teams have one (or in some cases four) players above that.

Is it a question of technique? Speed? Combinations?

8.34am BST

NRL - Try! Penrith 36-10 Newcastle (Leota)

59 min: This could get nasty for the Knights - the home fans are loving this. But surely they’re scratching their heads and wondering, where was this when they needed it earlier in the season?

It’s only the second time all season the Panthers have put on 30+ points. And to think they’ve beaten the Roosters, the Rabbits - plenty of other decent scalps along the way.

They really should be playing finals footy, Penrith.

8.32am BST

And after all that talk about Penrith struggling to find points in the NRL in 2019, they’ve suddenly turned into razzle-dazzlers!

There will be more to come now, no doubt - as Connor Watson is sent to the bin for slowing they play. Professional foul, goodbye!

8.27am BST

NRL - Try! Penrith 30-10 Newcastle (Egan)

52 min: And now it’s Burns’ housemate Wayde Egan who crashes over - but that was unbelievable work in the lead up by Willy Kikau! How has he stayed in field?! That was Lomu-esque!

Great strength, great determination and he keeps the ball alive to find his hooker back inside.

And just for a change, Cleary plugs another from the sideline.

Updated at 8.27am BST

8.22am BST

NRL - Try! Penrith 24-10 Newcastle (Burns)

50 min: It’s the kid Billy Burns who grabs the bounce-back try for the Panthers, and he’s buzzing the boy from Parkes! It’s his first in the NRL.

No mistake from Cleary who makes it 4/4. Let’s hope Bernard Foley’s watching.

8.15am BST

NRL - Try! Penrith 18-10 Newcastle (Ese’ese)

45 min: And they do make it count! It’s the bustling interchanger Herman Ese’ese (so good they named him twice) who gets over the line. Poor old Jimmy Maloney is spitting chips - he reckons it was a soft pen in the lead up, and replays suggest big question marks over a possible double movement. Anywho, game on!

8.12am BST

NRL - second half!

We’re back! And it’s the Knights starting with two penalties in quick succession - can they turn it into early scoreboard pressure? Was their a mini rev up inside the Newcastle sheds?

8.01am BST

An interesting saying from Paul Gallen post-match from Cronulla’s impressive win (see earlier) - apparently an old adage, but I for one had certainly never heard it. He said: the game was won early, even if the points came late - which was a pretty fair reflection of that from Penrith.

Strong defence from the home side over the first 20, and suddenly they were into the sheds with three tries under the belt. Sport really is a psychological ol’ contest.

7.58am BST

NRL - half-time: Penrith 18-4 Newcastle

And there ends the first forty! I wanted to say it’s been all Penrith, but remarkably it was the Knights with 54% of the pill. Some early repeat sets perhaps helping up that statistic, because certainly in terms of territory it was a half played predominantly just outside Newcastle’s line.

The margin a fair reflection, but for home fans they’ll be wondering where this clinical edge has suddenly come from.

7.50am BST

NRL - Try! Penrith 18-4 Newcastle (Cleary)

37 min: Ooh, he’s in a mood today! Cleary with just a second-ever career double, and again it comes from the halfback with his head up taking on the line. Quality work. More of this in 2020 from him, you’d hope.

And flawless again from the boot. Cleary 14-4 Knights.

Updated at 7.50am BST

7.48am BST

34 min: It may be the end of the season for both these sides but what a chance to run the rule over Generation Next. Former Knights legend Danny Buderus gives an update on the talent coming through Newcastle’s stable - it may have been a long six-years without finals footy for the faithful, but perhaps 2020 just could be one to get excited about for Novocastrians..

7.43am BST

Try - Penrith 12-4 Newcastle (To’o)

30 min: And apologies to anyone sweating on as-live-as-possible updates, I’ve just realised I was about four minutes behind on my Kayo. (Old dogs, new tricks etc).

It’s still Penrith on the front foot here, A great bust from Kikau gets the Panthers close, but desperate defence from Ponga keeps them out. But from seemingly nowhere, it’s To’o who takes it all upon himself! He’s jinked in from the outside - beats one, beats two, beats three, four, five - six! Remarkable run!

Cleary adds the extras. Magic stuff, Panthers.

Updated at 7.44am BST

7.38am BST

NRL - try! Penrith 6-4 Newcastle (Cleary)

26 min: I was just maligning the lack of runners getting on the end of good work from Nathan Cleary - he obviously thinks the same so he’s gone and done it all himself!

And he’s kicked the conversion himself. That all started from a clever short restart which they regathered to put the Knights straight back on the back foot. A great response to going behind!

7.34am BST

NRL - try! Penrith 0-4 Newcastle (Toa)

22 min: The highs and lows of professional footy! Minutes earlier the kid Starford Toa would have wanted the earth to open up and swallow him as he knocked-on on his own line. He’s more than made amends with a clever intercept out wide and it’s a 90m gallop to score his first NRL try in the corner!

The conversion attempt looks good - but it fades into the post!

Updated at 7.36am BST

7.32am BST

And another one you may have missed - hell of a howler this from the overnight European football qualifiers:

Related: Euro 2020 roundup: France find it easy after Albania anthem embarrassment

Here’s the vid of the players responding to the mystery anthem. Amazing reactions of pure mystification (apologies to Albanian fans for reliving this colossal %^&* up):

7.28am BST

15 min: They’re knocking at the door, the Panthers, but as they have all season, having done the hard work they just can’t broach (breach?) the Knights’ try-line.

What was that stat - worst cumulative try-scoring tally in 20+ years? Hard to believe with Maloney and Cleary in the halves, but doubt there will be a big off-season examination into where it’s gone wrong for Penrith.

Updated at 7.28am BST

7.23am BST

10 min: It’s backs-to-the-wall stuff early on for the Panthers who endure repeat sets, but they’re handed a big boost here as debutant winger Starford Toa comes unstuck under a swirling Cleary bomb. He’s spilled that, 5m outside his own line, as it bounces desperately off the youngster’s chest.

Can they make this count, Penrith?

Updated at 7.25am BST

7.20am BST

And for our northern hemisphere audience (or late night workers down under who have just emerged from hermetically sealed environments) - hasn’t there been a result at Flushing Meadows in the US Open women’s final.

The imperious Kevin Mitchell is your humble scribe:

History almost weighed both of them down, but it was Andreescu, younger by nearly 19 years – the biggest age gap in a slam final in the Open era – who held steady. It was the grand dame of tennis who cracked, despite launching a brave and desperate fightback in the second set.

Related: Bianca Andreescu stuns Serena Williams to win US Open final

7.15am BST

4 min: Oh wow. They were across the line, but they couldn’t ground it, the Panthers! The fullback Edwards came flying through to swoop on a Cleary grubber but he’s been taken out in a flying try-saver.. by the goal post! Absolutely collected, and the ball spills free! You don’t see that too often.

Updated at 7.25am BST

7.11am BST

NRL - Panthers v Knights - kickoff!

We’re away out in Sydney’s West from Panthers Stadium and it’s the irrepressible David Klemmer who takes the first hit up for the Knights. Look for James “Jimmy” Maloney to play with a wry smile on his face - it’s goodbye to another star of the game, let’s see if the Panthers can send him out a winner.

7.09am BST

If you missed the result from earlier this afternoon it was another inspiring performance from the Swifts’ sharpshooter Sam Wallace, as the one-time cellar-dwellers of the Super Netball book themselves a grand final berth. Terrific result for the club:

Related: NSW Swifts fly past Melbourne Vixens into Super Netball grand final

7.06am BST

The NRL doesn’t stop there however - if you thought that was the key fixture of the weekend, look again. It’s Knights v Panthers in the “oh, what could have been” derby. Both sides sitting a tantalising two points away from finals footy irrespective of a win today, but no doubt keen to give their fans one last cheer to salve a close but no cigar season.

Updated at 7.07am BST

7.02am BST

Footy, eh? From the childlike joy of Paul Gallen (if that’s a sentence you can write, let alone a concept you can get around) to the disappointment of Robbie Farah. Two colossi of the game, marking the end of their (regular season) careers in hugely divergent fashion - the latter saying goodbye to Leichhardt with pain etched all across his face.

They’ve not done it again, the Tigers. There will be no William Blake on the 433 bus back to Sydney CBD this evening.

Happier times for the folk from the Shire (I hope they’re well staffed at Engadine Maccas) and the people’s prince, PM Scott Morrison, who will travel home in better spirits. A finals showdown with Manly awaits them next week and the season stays alive!

Updated at 7.04am BST

6.58am BST

Ok, that’s all from me for now, Richard Parkin is your man to chaperone you through to the end of the day.

Updated at 6.58am BST

6.57am BST

NRL: Tigers 8-25 Sharks

The day began with the Tigers and Sharks in a sudden death finals eliminator. Seconds from half-time they still could not be separated. Ten minutes later and a three-try burst from Cronulla obliterated Wests and paved the way for a trip to Manly in the first week of the playoffs.

6.56am BST

NRL: 79 mins: Tigers 8-25 Sharks - Ha ha ha ha ha! Cronulla taking the p*** at Leichhardt Oval. With the Sharks’s final possession of the game Paul Gallen drops a goal from in front of the posts. That is very very cruel indeed.

Updated at 6.56am BST

6.50am BST

NRL: 75 mins: Tigers 8-24 Sharks - The Tigers have pushed and pushed but the Sharks are still in command of their own destiny.

6.35am BST

NRL: 62 mins: Tigers 8-24 Sharks - Brilliant from Luke Garner, can it spark a Tigers comeback? They’ll need Momirovski to kick better if they’re to stand any chance. That was an awful conversion miss.

6.26am BST

NRL: 55 mins: Tigers 4-24 Sharks - Robbie Farah is on for his final appearance as a Tiger at Leichhardt Oval. It’s going to take a miracle from the veteran to rescue Wests from here.

6.22am BST

NRL: 52 mins: Tigers 4-24 Sharks - What is happening out there!? Three tries in no time at all and the Sharks are blowing the Tigers out of the water.

Updated at 6.24am BST

6.19am BST

NRL: 49 mins: Tigers 4-18 Sharks - It was four-all in the shadows of half-time but now the Sharks are storming their way into the finals. Two tries in the blink of an eye since the break and now the Tigers have an uphill battle to keep their season alive.

6.15am BST

NRL: 46 mins: Tigers 4-12 Sharks - Who will make it into the finals? It’s looking like Cronulla after Josh Morris’s early second-half try.

6.13am BST

NRL: 45 mins: Tigers 4-6 Sharks - The second period is underway at Leichhardt Oval. Who will make it into the finals?

5.57am BST

Super Netball: Swifts 60-47 Vixens

The Swifts took this preliminary final by the scruff of the neck in the opening half and despite the best efforts of a desperate Vixens fightback that early lead always proved too much. As well as NSW performed Melbourne only have themselves to blame for a series of early shooting mishaps, then their failure to capitalise throughout the match when momentum was turning in their favour.

As predicted pregame Paige Hadley and Karen Moloney dominated the Nissan Net Points, the former named player of the match by Cath Cox.

The Swifts now travel to Brisbane for the 2019 Super Netball grand final against the Sunshine Coast Lightning. That’s next Sunday at 1pm.

Related: NSW Swifts fly past Melbourne Vixens into Super Netball grand final

Updated at 7.09am BST

5.53am BST

NRL: HT: Tigers 4-6 Sharks - Just two points separating these sides after a low scoring half at Leichhardt Oval. Surely, surely, this pair can’t engineer at draw and eliminate the Broncos, can they? This would rival West Germany v Austria in 1982!

5.48am BST

Super Netball: Q4: 5 mins remaining: Swifts 54-44 Vixens - Panic over Swifts fans. NSW have resisted all the Vixens can hurl at them and now they can look ahead to a grand final showdown.

5.43am BST

Super Netball: Q4: 8 mins remaining: Swifts 49-42 Vixens - Huge play by the Swifts, the ball went through hands for an age before Wallace finally put it away. The Vixens’s defence was impressive but the industry of Hadley and Housby eventually found the opening. It’s going to be hard for the Vixens to close the gap with so little time left.

5.41am BST

Super Netball: Q4: 11 mins remaining: Swifts 46-41 Vixens - The margin is down to five! The Swifts have lost all fluency around the circle and the visitors are chasing hard. But for the umpteenth time today Melbourne cannot really make NSW pay, fluffing their lines with a turnover goal on the cards.

5.39am BST

Super Netball: Q4: 12 mins remaining: Swifts 46-40 Vixens - The Vixens are still chasing...

5.34am BST

Super Netball: 3QT: Swifts 44-37 Vixens - The Vixens made up four points on the Swifts in that third quarter and threatened to bust the game wide open but they still trail by seven points at the final break. Total shots are now pretty much even but the Swifts are converting at 94%, the Vixens just 80%.

Updated at 5.35am BST

5.32am BST

NRL: 20 mins: Tigers 2-4 Sharks - The TMO works in Cronulla’s favour this time, Briton Nikora crossing for the opening try of the match following good work from Shaun Johnson. Not so good from the Kiwi seconds later though after his straightforward conversion struck the upright.

5.28am BST

Super Netball: Q3: 4 mins remaining: Swifts 40-35 Vixens - Oh boy! The Vixens have finally strung some goals together (seven of the last eight!) and the momentum is all their way. Their ball movement is suddenly rapid and mistakes are creeping into the Swifts’s game. This is getting nervy.

5.24am BST

Super Netball: Q3: 7 mins remaining: Swifts 39-31 Vixens - The Vixens are not giving up but the Swifts have stabilised in this third quarter. As has been the case throughout the match Melbourne have fashioned half-chances but been unable to finish the job only to find NSW ready to punish them as soon as they regain possession.

5.23am BST

NRL: 13 mins: Tigers 2-0 Sharks - The TMO rules No Try to the Sharks after Mulitalo almost capitalised on a chip and chase.

5.20am BST

Super Netball: Q3: 11 mins remaining: Swifts 36-28 Vixens - Time out called by the Swifts to settle this contest down after the Vixens burst out of the blocks after half-time. The margin is still eight points in the home side’s favour and Housby is still causing havoc around the circle, but the Swifts have been instructed to match the intensity of their visitors in the huddle.

5.16am BST

Super Netball: Q3: 13 mins remaining: Swifts 33-25 Vixens - The opening three goals in the third quarter all to the Vixens... could the comeback be on?

5.13am BST

NRL: 7 mins: Tigers 2-0 Sharks - Not much to report early on but the Tigers have an early lead after being gifted a penalty under the posts. That was followed up by Dugan belting the restart miles over the dead ball line to hand the Tigers good field position.

5.07am BST

5.06am BST

NRL: Tigers 0-0 Sharks - Underway at Leichhardt Oval in one of the moments of the NRL season. The beloved old ground has never looked better, packed to the rafters and bathed in sunshine, ready for a do-or-die contest between NSW rivals. The winner makes the finals, the loser can plan for 2020.

If that wasn’t enough there’s the late late selection drama with fan favourite Robbie Farah added to the 17 at the very last minute, the veteran leading his team out for the final time on home turf after replacing Corey Thompson after the prematch warm-up.

5.00am BST

Super Netball: HT: Swifts 33-22 Vixens - The Swifts have now won nine out of ten quarters against the Vixens this season and they are cruising towards a grand final date with the Lightning. The Vixens started the quarter impressively but a series of mistakes saw them fail to capitalise on their ascendancy and by the half-time siren they looked all out of momentum.

4.55am BST

NRL: Drama at Leichhardt Oval! Robbie Farah will play after all after Corey Thompson injured himself in the warm-up. What a contest this is going to be.

4.52am BST

Super Netball: Q2: 6 mins remaining: Swifts 28-17 Vixens - That early burst from the Vixens has fizzled out and the Swifts are back in control. Melbourne’s inability to craft an attack is letting them down possession after possession with Hail Mary passes going astray and chances around the circle going begging.

Hadley is dominating the Nissan Net Points while Kumwenda has impressed for the Vixens since her introduction.

4.48am BST

Super Netball: Q2: 9 mins remaining: Swifts 23-16 Vixens - Copy and paste. The Vixens are right back in this as a contest but time and again the passing chain comes unstuck around the circle. The margin should be much closer and the momentum should be all with the visitors but the Swifts maintain their handy lead.

4.45am BST

Super Netball: Q2: 12 mins remaining: Swifts 22-14 Vixens - The Vixens have come out with greater intensity this quarter, forcing a midcourt turnover, but again they fail to punish the Swifts and the margin remains intimidating.

4.38am BST

Super Netball: QT: Swifts 19-12 Vixens - How bad was that opening quarter for the Vixens? Thwaites has already been replaced by Kumwenda with the visitors shooting at just 67%, while Mannix has also been dragged from the other circle. They’re behind on intercepts (3-0), rebounds (3-0), and penalties (21-8). Is this one over already?

4.30am BST

Super Netball: Q1: 5 mins remaining: Swifts 15-7 Vixens - The Swifts are flying, the crowd is rocking, and the Vixens are stunned. Haythornthwaite is increasingly influential for the home side, feeding Samatha Wallace with ease.

4.27am BST

Super Netball: Q1: 8 mins remaining: Swifts 9-4 Vixens - Liz Ellis singled out Paige Hadley and Kate Moloney beforehand and they were both central to a pivotal passage of play that ended with the Swifts securing a five goal lead. First Moloney played a defence splitting pass that Thwaites was unable to finish before Hadley picked off a loose pass out of defence to feed Wallace and force the visitors into a time out.

Updated at 4.31am BST

4.24am BST

Super Netball: Q1: 10 mins remaining: Swifts 6-3 Vixens - It’s all the Swifts in these early exchanges with Helen Housby to the fore, finding space in the Vixens defence.

4.22am BST

Super Netball: Q1: 12 mins remaining: Swifts 3-0 Vixens - A nervy start from both teams with handling errors and turnovers aplenty but the Swifts look to be settling the quickest. Can the Vixens get a foothold?

4.19am BST

Super Netball: We’re underway in the preliminary final!

4.15am BST

Super Netball: Liz Ellis has singled out the match-up between Paige Hadley and Kate Moloney in the midcourt as the crucial battle in today’s contest. Moloney was outstanding last week when she was named player of the match against the Magpies, her intensity sparking a dynamic performance from the Vixens. Hadley was MVP when the Swifts won all four quarters in Melbourne back in round five.

4.08am BST

4.07am BST

NRL: The final team lists are in for the blockbuster between the Tigers and Sharks and there’s no place in the Wests 17 for Robbie Farah.

4.04am BST

Super Netball: The two sides are out on court warming up at a packed Quaycentre. Remember the Swifts have won this match-up twice already this season, and both with room to spare. However, the Vixens are bringing in plenty of momentum after a superb showing in their derby against the Magpies last week.

3.39am BST

Preamble

Hello everybody and welcome to another finals-focussed Sunday Sportwatch.

Today’s action begins in Super Netball with the Swifts hosting the Vixens for the right to travel to the Lightning in next week’s grand final. That one gets underway shortly after 1pm.

Then our attention turns to a very tasty finals decider in the NRL with the Tigers and Sharks facing off in an eliminator to see who makes the top eight. We’re underway at Leichhardt Oval around 2pm. There’s more NRL action later on with the Panthers and Knights from 4pm.

Around that we have the Ashes to discuss, a changing of the guard in women’s tennis at Flushing Meadows, the weekend’s AFL finals action, and the continued excellence of the Australian women’s cricket team - who are back in action tonight from 11.30pm in the West Indies.

As always, your contributions are welcomed, either in the comments section, by finding me on Twitter, or you can send me an email.

In the Super Netball the Sydney Swifts completed their metamorphosis from ugly cygnets to beautiful swans, qualifying for their first ever final. The imposing form of Noeline Taurua’s Sunshine Coast Lightning looms there though, as they look to make it three straight championships. Huge news overnight from the US Open with the shock upset of Serena Williams by teenage Canadian Bianca Andreescu (and there will of course be the matter of another tennis game later tonight - so stick around for that). Goodbye James Maloney, good night Newcastle Knights, and hello - the new era at the Panthers, heralded in some style by the Nathan Cleary show. They only scored above 30 points once all season - they’ve saved their best til last, Penrith. And it sees them finish an agonizing one point outside the NRL finals. The imperious Kevin Mitchell is your humble scribe: History almost weighed both of them down, but it was Andreescu, younger by nearly 19 years – the biggest age gap in a slam final in the Open era – who held steady. It was the grand dame of tennis who cracked, despite launching a brave and desperate fightback in the second set. 4 min: Oh wow. They were across the line, but they couldn’t ground it, the Panthers! The fullback Edwards came flying through to swoop on a Cleary grubber but he’s been taken out in a flying try-saver.. by the goal post! Absolutely collected, and the ball spills free! You don’t see that too often. NRL - Panthers v Knights - kickoff! We’re away out in Sydney’s West from Panthers Stadium and it’s the irrepressible David Klemmer who takes the first hit up for the Knights. Look for James “Jimmy” Maloney to play with a wry smile on his face - it’s goodbye to another star of the game, let’s see if the Panthers can send him out a winner. If you missed the result from earlier this afternoon it was another inspiring performance from the Swifts’ sharpshooter Sam Wallace, as the one-time cellar-dwellers of the Super Netball book themselves a grand final berth. Terrific result for the club: The NRL doesn’t stop there however - if you thought that was the key fixture of the weekend, look again. It’s Knights v Panthers in the “oh, what could have been” derby. Both sides sitting a tantalising two points away from finals footy irrespective of a win today, but no doubt keen to give their fans one last cheer to salve a close but no cigar season. Footy, eh? From the childlike joy of Paul Gallen (if that’s a sentence you can write, let alone a concept you can get around) to the disappointment of Robbie Farah. Two colossi of the game, marking the end of their (regular season) careers in hugely divergent fashion - the latter saying goodbye to Leichhardt with pain etched all across his face. They’ve not done it again, the Tigers. There will be no William Blake on the 433 bus back to Sydney CBD this evening. Happier times for the folk from the Shire (I hope they’re well staffed at Engadine Maccas) and the people’s prince, PM Scott Morrison, who will travel home in better spirits. A finals showdown with Manly awaits them next week and the season stays alive! Ok, that’s all from me for now, Richard Parkin is your man to chaperone you through to the end of the day. The day began with the Tigers and Sharks in a sudden death finals eliminator. Seconds from half-time they still could not be separated. Ten minutes later and a three-try burst from Cronulla obliterated Wests and paved the way for a trip to Manly in the first week of the playoffs. NRL: 79 mins: Tigers 8-25 Sharks - Ha ha ha ha ha! Cronulla taking the p*** at Leichhardt Oval. With the Sharks’s final possession of the game Paul Gallen drops a goal from in front of the posts. That is very very cruel indeed. NRL: 75 mins: Tigers 8-24 Sharks - The Tigers have pushed and pushed but the Sharks are still in command of their own destiny. NRL: 62 mins: Tigers 8-24 Sharks - Brilliant from Luke Garner, can it spark a Tigers comeback? They’ll need Momirovski to kick better if they’re to stand any chance. That was an awful conversion miss. NRL: 55 mins: Tigers 4-24 Sharks - Robbie Farah is on for his final appearance as a Tiger at Leichhardt Oval. It’s going to take a miracle from the veteran to rescue Wests from here. NRL: 52 mins: Tigers 4-24 Sharks - What is happening out there!? Three tries in no time at all and the Sharks are blowing the Tigers out of the water. NRL: 49 mins: Tigers 4-18 Sharks - It was four-all in the shadows of half-time but now the Sharks are storming their way into the finals. Two tries in the blink of an eye since the break and now the Tigers have an uphill battle to keep their season alive. NRL: 46 mins: Tigers 4-12 Sharks - Who will make it into the finals? It’s looking like Cronulla after Josh Morris’s early second-half try. NRL: 45 mins: Tigers 4-6 Sharks - The second period is underway at Leichhardt Oval. Who will make it into the finals? The Swifts took this preliminary final by the scruff of the neck in the opening half and despite the best efforts of a desperate Vixens fightback that early lead always proved too much. As well as NSW performed Melbourne only have themselves to blame for a series of early shooting mishaps, then their failure to capitalise throughout the match when momentum was turning in their favour. As predicted pregame Paige Hadley and Karen Moloney dominated the Nissan Net Points, the former named player of the match by Cath Cox. The Swifts now travel to Brisbane for the 2019 Super Netball grand final against the Sunshine Coast Lightning. That’s next Sunday at 1pm. NRL: HT: Tigers 4-6 Sharks - Just two points separating these sides after a low scoring half at Leichhardt Oval. Surely, surely, this pair can’t engineer at draw and eliminate the Broncos, can they? This would rival West Germany v Austria in 1982! Super Netball: Q4: 5 mins remaining: Swifts 54-44 Vixens - Panic over Swifts fans. NSW have resisted all the Vixens can hurl at them and now they can look ahead to a grand final showdown. Super Netball: Q4: 8 mins remaining: Swifts 49-42 Vixens - Huge play by the Swifts, the ball went through hands for an age before Wallace finally put it away. The Vixens’s defence was impressive but the industry of Hadley and Housby eventually found the opening. It’s going to be hard for the Vixens to close the gap with so little time left. Super Netball: Q4: 11 mins remaining: Swifts 46-41 Vixens - The margin is down to five! The Swifts have lost all fluency around the circle and the visitors are chasing hard. But for the umpteenth time today Melbourne cannot really make NSW pay, fluffing their lines with a turnover goal on the cards. Super Netball: Q4: 12 mins remaining: Swifts 46-40 Vixens - The Vixens are still chasing... Super Netball: 3QT: Swifts 44-37 Vixens - The Vixens made up four points on the Swifts in that third quarter and threatened to bust the game wide open but they still trail by seven points at the final break. Total shots are now pretty much even but the Swifts are converting at 94%, the Vixens just 80%. NRL: 20 mins: Tigers 2-4 Sharks - The TMO works in Cronulla’s favour this time, Briton Nikora crossing for the opening try of the match following good work from Shaun Johnson. Not so good from the Kiwi seconds later though after his straightforward conversion struck the upright. Super Netball: Q3: 4 mins remaining: Swifts 40-35 Vixens - Oh boy! The Vixens have finally strung some goals together (seven of the last eight!) and the momentum is all their way. Their ball movement is suddenly rapid and mistakes are creeping into the Swifts’s game. This is getting nervy. Super Netball: Q3: 7 mins remaining: Swifts 39-31 Vixens - The Vixens are not giving up but the Swifts have stabilised in this third quarter. As has been the case throughout the match Melbourne have fashioned half-chances but been unable to finish the job only to find NSW ready to punish them as soon as they regain possession. NRL: 13 mins: Tigers 2-0 Sharks - The TMO rules No Try to the Sharks after Mulitalo almost capitalised on a chip and chase. Super Netball: Q3: 11 mins remaining: Swifts 36-28 Vixens - Time out called by the Swifts to settle this contest down after the Vixens burst out of the blocks after half-time. The margin is still eight points in the home side’s favour and Housby is still causing havoc around the circle, but the Swifts have been instructed to match the intensity of their visitors in the huddle. Super Netball: Q3: 13 mins remaining: Swifts 33-25 Vixens - The opening three goals in the third quarter all to the Vixens... could the comeback be on? NRL: 7 mins: Tigers 2-0 Sharks - Not much to report early on but the Tigers have an early lead after being gifted a penalty under the posts. That was followed up by Dugan belting the restart miles over the dead ball line to hand the Tigers good field position. NRL: Tigers 0-0 Sharks - Underway at Leichhardt Oval in one of the moments of the NRL season. The beloved old ground has never looked better, packed to the rafters and bathed in sunshine, ready for a do-or-die contest between NSW rivals. The winner makes the finals, the loser can plan for 2020. If that wasn’t enough there’s the late late selection drama with fan favourite Robbie Farah added to the 17 at the very last minute, the veteran leading his team out for the final time on home turf after replacing Corey Thompson after the prematch warm-up. Super Netball: HT: Swifts 33-22 Vixens - The Swifts have now won nine out of ten quarters against the Vixens this season and they are cruising towards a grand final date with the Lightning. The Vixens started the quarter impressively but a series of mistakes saw them fail to capitalise on their ascendancy and by the half-time siren they looked all out of momentum. NRL: Drama at Leichhardt Oval! Robbie Farah will play after all after Corey Thompson injured himself in the warm-up. What a contest this is going to be. Super Netball: Q2: 6 mins remaining: Swifts 28-17 Vixens - That early burst from the Vixens has fizzled out and the Swifts are back in control. Melbourne’s inability to craft an attack is letting them down possession after possession with Hail Mary passes going astray and chances around the circle going begging. Hadley is dominating the Nissan Net Points while Kumwenda has impressed for the Vixens since her introduction. Super Netball: Q2: 9 mins remaining: Swifts 23-16 Vixens - Copy and paste. The Vixens are right back in this as a contest but time and again the passing chain comes unstuck around the circle. The margin should be much closer and the momentum should be all with the visitors but the Swifts maintain their handy lead. Super Netball: Q2: 12 mins remaining: Swifts 22-14 Vixens - The Vixens have come out with greater intensity this quarter, forcing a midcourt turnover, but again they fail to punish the Swifts and the margin remains intimidating. Super Netball: QT: Swifts 19-12 Vixens - How bad was that opening quarter for the Vixens? Thwaites has already been replaced by Kumwenda with the visitors shooting at just 67%, while Mannix has also been dragged from the other circle. They’re behind on intercepts (3-0), rebounds (3-0), and penalties (21-8). Is this one over already? Super Netball: Q1: 5 mins remaining: Swifts 15-7 Vixens - The Swifts are flying, the crowd is rocking, and the Vixens are stunned. Haythornthwaite is increasingly influential for the home side, feeding Samatha Wallace with ease. Super Netball: Q1: 8 mins remaining: Swifts 9-4 Vixens - Liz Ellis singled out Paige Hadley and Kate Moloney beforehand and they were both central to a pivotal passage of play that ended with the Swifts securing a five goal lead. First Moloney played a defence splitting pass that Thwaites was unable to finish before Hadley picked off a loose pass out of defence to feed Wallace and force the visitors into a time out. Super Netball: Q1: 10 mins remaining: Swifts 6-3 Vixens - It’s all the Swifts in these early exchanges with Helen Housby to the fore, finding space in the Vixens defence. Super Netball: Q1: 12 mins remaining: Swifts 3-0 Vixens - A nervy start from both teams with handling errors and turnovers aplenty but the Swifts look to be settling the quickest. Can the Vixens get a foothold? Super Netball: We’re underway in the preliminary final! Super Netball: Liz Ellis has singled out the match-up between Paige Hadley and Kate Moloney in the midcourt as the crucial battle in today’s contest. Moloney was outstanding last week when she was named player of the match against the Magpies, her intensity sparking a dynamic performance from the Vixens. Hadley was MVP when the Swifts won all four quarters in Melbourne back in round five. NRL: The final team lists are in for the blockbuster between the Tigers and Sharks and there’s no place in the Wests 17 for Robbie Farah. Super Netball: The two sides are out on court warming up at a packed Quaycentre. Remember the Swifts have won this match-up twice already this season, and both with room to spare. However, the Vixens are bringing in plenty of momentum after a superb showing in their derby against the Magpies last week. Hello everybody and welcome to another finals-focussed Sunday Sportwatch. Today’s action begins in Super Netball with the Swifts hosting the Vixens for the right to travel to the Lightning in next week’s grand final. That one gets underway shortly after 1pm. Then our attention turns to a very tasty finals decider in the NRL with the Tigers and Sharks facing off in an eliminator to see who makes the top eight. We’re underway at Leichhardt Oval around 2pm. There’s more NRL action later on with the Panthers and Knights from 4pm. Around that we have the Ashes to discuss, a changing of the guard in women’s tennis at Flushing Meadows, the weekend’s AFL finals action, and the continued excellence of the Australian women’s cricket team - who are back in action tonight from 11.30pm in the West Indies. As always, your contributions are welcomed, either in the comments section, by finding me on Twitter, or you can send me an email.

webTitle: All trust is gone ... and the PM only has one way out

fields.headline: All trust is gone ... and the PM only has one way out
fields.standfirst: The former minister, who lost the whip along with 20 other Tory rebels, argues Johnson’s only hope is to do a deal with the EU
fields.trailText: The former minister, who lost the whip along with 20 other Tory rebels, argues Johnson’s only hope is to do a deal with the EU
fields.body:
The phrase “fingertip control” is used by parliamentary whips to disguise panic in government as policies and votes dip perilously close to the wire. There are few fingertips left at Westminster now. I have never seen a government strategy so misjudged, nor fail so speedily, as that devised in Downing Street since late July.

The errors began with the reconstituting of the Vote Leave team at No 10, making the classic error of fighting the next war like the last, assuming, with the arrogance of years of despising politicians and Westminster, that running government was easy if you cut out the middle-men.

Secret plans were laid, despite public denials, to prorogue parliament for a lengthy spell. When announced, this required ministers uneasily to claim that it was merely business as usual for a Queen’s speech, making them look evasive. Last Tuesday, MPs – later that day to lose the whip – met the PM in Downing Street. Boris Johnson was told sharply how damaging prorogation had been. Colleagues returning to Westminster to support his efforts in Berlin and Paris, giving him the time we thought we had, now saw the rug pulled from under our feet, thus forcing early the measure to protect against no deal.

That error had been compounded by Michael Gove’s ambiguity about obeying the law, and then crucially by public signalling that a vote against the government would be treated as a confidence vote, and the whip withdrawn from those rebelling. With no support for a Corbyn confidence vote, the government’s decision seemed deliberate – to provoke a confrontation.

I do not know if this follows a decision to purge the party of moderates like us, as advocated in some Tory circles, or if it was a crude attempt to see us fold under pressure. Either way they would win.

They got their result. Whoever doubted the government’s contempt for our expression of constituents’ concerns had to endure the arrogance and inexplicable performance of Jacob Rees-Mogg responding to the debate. Hearts were hardened, a Rubicon was crossed. The rest, as they may say, is history.

No one will be fooled into supporting an election before 31 October. Whatever attempt the government makes, it is doomed to failure

This also means no one will be fooled into supporting an election before 31 October. Whatever attempt the government makes, either trying a vote of confidence in itself, or trying to run a one-clause bill to get round the fixed-term legislation, it is doomed to failure. The resulting lack of trust has been fatal to that.

There is an answer. The EU is indeed watching the government’s control of the Commons and wants to know if a deal agreed will get its support, but so far the government has the wrong people in its sights. If we are to leave on 31 October, we must agree a deal at the European Council. Boris Johnson can achieve this, but only if he tackles those who stopped it before. He needs to scrap his present strategy. He should stop insulting a divided opposition, and work with those who want to leave, and also square up to the ERG, the elephants in the room last week.

They now need to be told that he is doing a new deal, but based on the withdrawal agreement, still the only thing agreed between 28 states. If they do not vote for it, they will follow us out of the party without a whip, and a Conservative election victory is improbable if we have not left. Brexit will vanish if the Tories lose, and millions will dance on its grave. The ERG, so close to everything they desired in 2016, will have stuffed it up and lost it.

Vote for the deal, he will say. I’d love to be there.

Alistair Burt, Conservative MP for North East Bedfordshire, will stand down at the next election

webTitle: Fallen out with the neighbours? Time to build a ‘spite house’

fields.headline: Fallen out with the neighbours? Time to build a ‘spite house’
fields.standfirst: Paint it in red and white stripes and your unhappy neighbours will soon get the message
fields.trailText: Paint it in red and white stripes and your unhappy neighbours will soon get the message, says Eva Wiseman
fields.body:
Until the age of 16 I went to school in a suburb of extreme good taste, where locals were required to maintain their properties according to an ancient and densely illustrated binder of rules about gate heights and hedges. Walking back to the bus stop, through a small stretch of woodland planted with the most polite of flashers, then along slim clean roads, my friends and I would often be moved to scream. Perhaps this experience, of moving in uniform among enforced lawns, contributes to my glee, my utter dripping glee, at the existence of “spite houses”.

The latest example is in a ritzy neighbourhood in Manhattan Beach, California, where a woman called Kathryn Kidd was reported to the city by neighbours for listing her home on Airbnb. Her response was to paint the house fuchsia and cover it with 3ft tall emojis, including one with its mouth zipped shut. Kidd insisted she’d chosen this design a) because she is an art collector, b) as a message to young women to cover up their bodies and c) because she loves emojis. Neighbours instead read them as a sign to “zip their lip”.

Part of my love of the spite house is the way it questions what a house is for

In the UK, the most recent spite house to make the papers was the Kensington home of Zipporah Lisle-Mainwaring, a property developer who painted candy stripes on the three-storey façade of her house in 2015. She denied that the stripes were to spite neighbours who objected to her plans to demolish the £4.75m property, which she used “for storage”. Still, they were quoted as being “horrendously unhappy”. In 2017, she won her battle to knock it down and build a new house, with gym, cinema room and art gallery, in its place. The neighbours remain gloriously displeased.

I dance through these stories as if in a meadow. There have been plenty throughout history, from the righteous (a rainbow-painted bungalow across the street from the comically homophobic Westboro Baptist Church) to the petty (built to obstruct a neighbour’s view), and each one stands proud in brick, its middle finger raised like a chimney. Part of my love of the spite house is the way it questions what a house is for. As has been proven elsewhere by the erection of glass and steel buildings intended to be used as oligarchs’ safety deposit boxes rather than homes, the myth that a house is built simply for people to sleep and eat and bathe in has long been debunked. Instead they are objects of war and anxiety, two-up, two-down, too much.

In Rachel Cusk’s new collection of essays, she writes about the effect it had on her to redecorate her house. Looking around her newly painted home, she felt a “certain sense of shame” at having caused walls to be knocked down and floors to be ripped up and rooms to be gutted, at causing the past to be obliterated. She saw a hidden part of herself exposed – the private decisions she’d made were exhibited for all to see. The domestic, she explains (and I imagine her writing this at a desk so exquisite it hovers half an inch above the ground) is more concerned with seeming than with being – personal ideas are externalised and failings made real.

A fan of Cusk’s bracing work, I spent a happy afternoon poring over pictures of her current home on an estate agent’s website that I frequent, being also a fan of existential pain. A divine and brutal mansion on the Norfolk coast where she lives with her third husband, it is elevated further by Cusk’s musings on property.

“People always buy the house,” she says in captions accompanying the photos, “for the stage of life they’ve just passed through. When something’s completed it’s often the moment that you suddenly understand what it is you’ve wanted and needed.”

In the New York Times that same day I was introduced to the 1990s architecture of Madeline Gins and Shusaku Arakawa, who designed homes to allow their inhabitants eternal life. Their method was this: make them deeply uncomfortable. A brightly painted bathroom has no door, but it does have two toilets, plumbed back to back.

Spite is a perfectly valid reason to build a house. Five years ago psychologists started studying spite and, using game theory, found that when it was used to punish other spiteful players (a person building the narrowest house in the country, perhaps, in the back-alley their neighbour coveted) the overall outcome was a decline in spiteful exchanges, leading to new stability. Plus, it feels good. In Romanian folklore a genie tells a peasant he can have anything he wants, but his neighbour will get twice as much. The peasant says, firmly: “Put out one of my eyes.” I picture the owner of the emoji house chuckling similarly over a pumpkin spice latte, calm in the knowledge that homes have become abstracted to the point of metaphor, that houses are machines for sulking in. And her rental glows pinkly in the corner of her sightline, providing constant reassurance that she is not the only person that suffers.

Email Eva at e.wiseman@observer.co.uk or follow her on Twitter@EvaWiseman

webTitle: Oh, I don’t like to be beside the seaside… and luckily the boy doesn’t seem to either

fields.headline: Oh, I don’t like to be beside the seaside… and luckily the boy doesn’t seem to either
fields.standfirst: Slippery sand underfoot is bad enough, but swallowed is an entirely different horribleness – as my son soon discovered
fields.trailText: Slippery sand underfoot is bad enough, but swallowed is an entirely different horribleness – as my son soon discovered
fields.body:
We brought the boy to Wexford last week, for his first time at the seafront. I gamely grinned and made fun, hoping to instil in him a passion for the beach, but also secretly harbouring a hope that he’d see through it all, like I do.

‘I don’t like sand,’ Anakin Skywalker once said. ‘It’s coarse and rough and irritating and it gets everywhere.’ There are few things on which Darth Vader and I agree – I found his destruction of the planet Alderaan, for example, highly unreasonable – but on this we concur. It’s cheap to decry something popular and await the outrage to pour in, but also beaches are rubbish and everyone who likes them is thick.

For one thing, it’s weird that liking long walks on the beach has become a cliché pastime, as if everyone likes the practice. I’m astonished that anyone does. Try it in shoes and you slip constantly, in footwear that quickly fills with abrasive dust if the sand is dry, and slimy beige clay if it’s wet. Do you like this? Do you like wet feet and ruined shoes? And if we’re walking barefoot, then you feel every last squish of the stuff filling the cavities between your toes, or else burning the soles of your feet if you’re silly enough to do so on a hot day.

He stepped on the shifting mulch and grimaced with disdain as he pumped great fistfuls of sand into his waiting mouth

People say they love the smell of the sea, which is odd because, spoiler alert, it smells like a giant roiling soup of salt, vegetation and fish arses. I don’t want to stray into hyperbole here, sea air is nice enough from a mildly distant veranda, or a pleasant little beachfront café, where the full-strength stench of fish foam has been diluted by nice normal smells like traffic and fags. But right there on the shifting mess of fossilised silt that you call a pleasant surface? No thanks.

My feelings on the recent heatwave are well-known – I was against it – so I will concede that being by the seaside in such weather does moderate its effects. Tragically, Irish people go to the beach in all weather and none, meaning we took our boy in 12C heat and spitting wind, under a sky the colour of a switched-off telly. After so horribly letting me down with his passion for the sun, some shameful part of me was glad when he took to the beach in his spangly little wetsuit with a look to his mother that seemed to say, ‘Really?’

‘That’s my boy,’ I thought as he gingerly stepped on the shifting mulch and then grimaced with disdain as he pumped great fistfuls of sand into his waiting mouth. We washed it out with ice-cream from a nicely appointed veranda nearby, and I imagined a lifetime spent happily in each other’s company, enjoying the true benefits of the seaside while less discerning beach hoppers crowd the teeming sands.

Not that this was the last I saw of the sand that day. On changing his nappy that night, I found quite a lot of it had come through the other end. It really does get everywhere after all.

webTitle: Whose Story is This?; Trick Mirror; Coventry – review

fields.headline: Whose Story is This?; Trick Mirror; Coventry – review
fields.standfirst: Essay collections from Rebecca Solnit, Jia Tolentino and Rachel Cusk chronicle the way we live now
fields.trailText: Essay collections from Rebecca Solnit, Jia Tolentino and Rachel Cusk chronicle the way we live now
fields.body:
In recent years the essay has been revitalised as a form by a new generation of women whose writing gives urgent voice to the old adage that the personal is political. In marrying lived experience with the rigours of investigative journalism and critical analysis, these writers on both sides of the Atlantic are illuminating cultural and political changes in a way that recalls the heyday of the essay form in the work of Susan Sontag and Joan Didion.

The pre-eminent voice among them is Rebecca Solnit, whose work has moved from cult status to mainstream here and in the US since the viral success of her 2008 essay Men Explain Things to Me, credited with identifying the phenomenon of “mansplaining” (though the word is not hers).

Approaching 60, Solnit was described as an activist long before the term was commonplace, and much of her writing has been born from her immersion in protest movements, notably around environmental issues and the rights of indigenous peoples. Her slim 2005 book, Hope in the Dark, was reissued in 2016 in the wake of Trump’s election, as a manifesto and a rallying cry for progressives.

Whose Story Is This? continues the preoccupation of her last collection, The Mother of All Questions, with the issue of whose voices are legitimised and whose silenced.

“Who gets to be the subject of the story is an immensely political question,” she notes in the title essay, in which she tackles the myth of a “real” America (white, male and working class) disproportionately pandered to by the right. It’s a question she examines here most prominently in relation to women’s rights, from the testimony of Christine Blasey Ford to the rise of the incel movement.

Solnit has been criticised on occasion by younger feminists for the fact that her essays are exercises in consciousness-raising, often stating the obvious without proposing concrete solutions beyond telling our stories. She appears to address this obliquely in the introductory piece, by pointing out that “we live inside ideas”, and emphasising that the reshaping of these ideas over time demands work. “It’s easy now to assume that one’s perspectives on race, gender, orientation and the rest are signs of inherent virtue, but a lot of ideas currently in circulation are gifts that arrived recently, through the labours of others.”

The frankness with which Jia Tolentino expresses self-doubt and confusion seems an apt reflection of the culture she investigates

Solnit’s quote on the jacket of Jia Tolentino’s debut collection, Trick Mirror – “the best young essayist at work in the United States” – suggests that she has already appointed her successor. Tolentino, 30, came of age as a writer for the feminist website Jezebel, before moving to the New Yorker, and her essays reflect a sensibility formed in that environment: “flogging my own selfhood on the internet”, as she describes it.

She is upfront in her introduction about the obvious self-absorption of the personal essay – “writing is either a way to shed my self-delusions or a way to develop them” – and if her arguments lack the elegant certainties of a writer such as Solnit, the frankness with which she expresses self-doubt and confusion seems an apt reflection of the cultural currents she sets out to investigate.

Personal experience figures prominently in the pieces here, from her teenage experience on an early reality TV show, to growing up in an evangelical megachurch that was “so big we called it the Repentagon”.

Elsewhere, she considers the social and cultural pressures on young women in Always Be Optimizing, a whistlestop drive through the vast subject of feminism and the beauty myth, in the light of her obsession with barre class. “We were lucky, I thought, dissociating, to even be able to indulge these awful priorities, to have the economic capital to be able to accrue more social capital via our looks.”

If the essay holds up the absurdity of desiring this commodification of ourselves while acknowledging the awfulness of it, without offering answers, this is entirely in keeping with the spirit of the book: the act of inquiry is worthwhile in itself, if only in ensuring that we are not sleepwalking. Regardless, Tolentino offers a sharp eye that cuts through the multiple distorted reflections thrown back at women by the culture that surrounds us.

Rachel Cusk has always written fearlessly about personal experience as a way of considering the expectations on women, from the inequalities of motherhood to the destruction and reinvention that comes with divorce, and has often faced considerable backlash from other women for her frankness, so a new collection of her nonfiction is always to be eagerly anticipated.

The first section, which contains the title essay, gathers a series of reflections on a particular stage of mid-life. Making Home and Lions on Leashes consider the reconfiguring of identity that comes with the point at which teenage children outgrow their home, and what the idea of “home” means as a woman and a writer.

Cusk is rarely political in the explicit sense, but On Rudeness begins with an observation of immigration officers at an airport in the aftermath of the 2016 EU referendum and expands to examine the role of language and expression in the social divisions made visible by the vote. Cusk’s unsparing ability to see links between her own experience and broader literary and historical perspectives has always elevated her personal writing above mere memoir, and this collection cements her reputation as one of the most fierce and elegant chroniclers of how we live now.

webTitle: Seven in 10 hospital trusts failing to meet safety standards

fields.headline: Seven in 10 hospital trusts failing to meet safety standards
fields.standfirst: Staff shortages put patients put at risk, say Care Quality Commission inspection reports
fields.trailText: Staff shortages put patients put at risk, say Care Quality Commission inspection reports
fields.body:
Patient safety is frequently at risk in NHS hospital trusts in England, with 70% of them failing to meet national safety standards, according to an Observer analysis of inspection reports, with staff shortages the biggest problem.

Reports by the regulator the Care Quality Commission (CQC) reveal that managers at one trust failed to act on staff reports of abuse and violence, while a shortage of critical beds at another trust led to three serious incidents resulting in patient harm.

Of 148 acute and general hospital trusts, safety standards at 96 are rated as “requires improvement” by the CQC; six are rated inadequate, the lowest category. The others are rated good, with none outstanding.

Of the 14 inspection reports published since the start of June, half raised concerns over inadequate staffing levels. One trust, Imperial College Healthcare in London, “did not always have enough staff with the right qualifications, skills, training and experience to keep people safe from avoidable harm and abuse and to provide the right care and treatment”.

Shrewsbury and Telford hospital trust was rated inadequate for safety last year. The number of nurses in its urgent and emergency services was “not sufficient to manage the department safely”, and the inspectors “saw these low staffing levels directly impact on patients’ safe care and treatment”. Nurses who had not received the right support or training had to co-ordinate the department for two months before the inspection because of staff shortages. A trust spokesman told the Observer improvements were being made.

Rob Harwood, chair of the consultants committee at the British Medical Association, said: “With the NHS chronically underfunded and understaffed for many years, those working there are increasingly expected to deliver care in an unsafe, unsupportive environment, putting the safety of our patients at risk.

“As well as delivering the urgent investment needed on the frontline, the government must get a grip on the workforce crisis to ensure safe staffing levels in the NHS and change the current pension rules in order to retain and motivate its workers rather than pushing them to vote with their feet.”

Helga Pile, deputy head of health at the trade union Unison, said: “One in every 10 posts in the NHS is vacant because of a shameful failure of workforce planning, and it’s staff and patients who are paying the price.

One in every 10 posts in the NHS is vacant and it’s staff and patients who are paying the price

Helga Pile

“Patients aren’t getting the care they deserve while exhausted health staff are routinely being asked to do more with fewer resources.

“Sustained government investment is needed across the NHS and health professions need to become more attractive career options. Funding for large-scale degree apprenticeship programmes would be a game changer.”

Imperial College Healthcare did not respond to a request for comment.

Aside from staff shortages and inadequate training, other failings identified in recent CQC reports include:

• Three serious incidents resulted in patient harm as a consequence of critical care beds not being available at South Tees hospital trust

• Managers at Walsall Healthcare trust failed to act on staff reports of abuse and violence

• Overcrowding at the Princess Royal University Hospital in London, with patients cared for on trolleys in corridors and at times two patients being nursed in single-person cubicles

• Significant handover delays for patients arriving by ambulance, also at Princess Royal

• The design and use of facilities in the emergency department at the Queen Elizabeth Hospital in King’s Lynn did not always keep patients with mental health concerns safe, while patients did not always receive medication at the right time.

A spokesperson for King’s College Hospital NHS Foundation Trust, which runs the Princess Royal, said: “We are fully committed to improving the safety, quality and experience of patient care within the urgent and emergency care services at the Princess Royal University Hospital. Since before the publication of the CQC’s report, the trust had begun to implement a programme of improvements within the department to address the concerns that were raised.”

Despite the dire national picture, safety standards are slowly improving over time - around 85% of NHS acute and general hospital trusts have been rated substandard for safety at some point during the last five years, and the number rated Inadequate has fallen sharply.

Brighton and Sussex University Hospitals trust’s safety rating was upgraded from Inadequate to Good in January after inspectors found numerous improvements had been made, with the trust maintaining adequate staffing levels - though even then, the lack of registered nurses remained a “significant challenge”.

A Department of Health and Social Care spokesperson said: “The safety of patients is paramount and all hospitals are required by law to have the right staff in the right place at the right time.

“There are 16,800 more nurses on our wards than in 2010 with 52,000 more in training and to help retain our dedicated staff we are providing more flexibility and career development alongside multi-year pay rises for junior doctors and over a million other NHS workers, including nurses.”

webTitle: A book, then a play, now Litvinenko’s story is coming back to the small screen | Richard Brooks

fields.headline: A book, then a play, now Litvinenko’s story is coming back to the small screen
fields.standfirst: The murdered Russian dissident’s case is to become an ITV drama. And the National Gallery gets first dibs on a baroque masterpiece
fields.trailText: The murdered Russian dissident’s case is to become an ITV drama. And the National Gallery gets first dibs on a baroque masterpiece
fields.body:
David Tennant is being lined up to play the murdered Russian dissident Alexander Litvinenko in a TV drama. Following Litvinenko’s poisoning in London in 2006, the case has since proved popular for adaptation and retelling. A play, A Very Expensive Poison, about his assassination has just opened at the Old Vic, itself loosely based on the book of the same name by Guardian journalist Luke Harding. Now ITV has a script from George Kay, who penned two episodes of Killing Eve, and whose 12-part drama, Criminal, premieres on Netflix later this month.

Tennant, a former Doctor Who, a cop from Broadchurch, and now a lead in Criminal, is favoured as Litvinenko. The TV series is itself based on Channel 4’s 2017 documentary Hunting the KGB Killers, whose producer, Richard Kerbaj, is behind the ITV series, along with drama veteran Patrick Spence.

Orazio Gentileschi’s The Finding of Moses has hung in the National Gallery since 2002. Graham Kirkham, who made his fortune with the furniture firm DFS, is believed to have owned the baroque masterpiece for two decades, and he is now selling it. Kirkham, a Tory donor ennobled in 1999, has not gone to an auction house, where it would probably have been sold abroad, but chosen to give the National first dibs. Easily Britain’s wealthiest gallery, the National can afford the price tag of around £35m.

These days, however, many owners do not give British galleries a decent chance to buy. So, in August alone, the government placed export bars on three very pricey works that had been in private hands – Monet’s Le Palais Ducal, Turner’s The Dark Rigi and Millais’s Ferdinand Lured by Ariel. All had been bought through British auction houses by foreign buyers, helped by a weak pound to make them a comparative snip. The Department for Digital, Culture, Media and Sport imposed these bars to give galleries a few months to find the cash to match the overseas bids.

However, one weakness in the system is that any work can be withdrawn by the buyer from an interested gallery during the money-raising period – rather like a house deal can be reneged upon before exchange of contracts. This loophole has led to 13 works being withdrawn over the past decade before a British gallery could raise the cash. The most notable example was Pontormo’s Portrait of a Young Man in a Red Cap. In that instance it was the National Gallery that then missed out.

Tessa Hadley is, I reckon, Britain’s most stylish and perceptive living female novelist. But none of her seven novels, including her most recent, Late in the Day, has ever been longlisted for the Booker prize. Maybe because she examines family relationships and (shock, horror) the middle classes, she is overlooked by judges too often won over by the flashy and the lengthy. So, in last week’s Booker shortlist, there is Salman Rushdie’s Quichotte, a retelling of Don Quixote in the modern-day US, and Ducks, Newburyport by Lucy Ellmann, an eight-sentence monologue of 1,000 pages.

Maybe because she examines family relationships and (shock, horror) the middle classes, she is overlooked by judges too often won over by the flashy and the lengthy. So, in last week’s Booker shortlist, there is Salman Rushdie’s Quichotte, a retelling of Don Quixote in the modern-day US, and Ducks, Newburyport by Lucy Ellmann, an eight-sentence monologue of 1,000 pages.

webTitle: Mother searches for answers a year after daughter set herself on fire in council housing office

fields.headline: Mother searches for answers a year after daughter set herself on fire in council housing office
fields.standfirst: Grieving mother still has questions over daughter’s death which followed months of anxiety over eviction threat
fields.trailText: Grieving mother still has questions over daughter’s death which followed months of anxiety over eviction threat
fields.body:
It is a year since Melanie Smith walked into the housing offices of Barnet council and set herself on fire.

Yet her mother, Marie Bennett, fears vital lessons that could protect others have not been learned. “This didn’t need to happen – that’s the thing that hurts,” Bennett said. “I don’t think anyone has taken on board that they could maybe prevent other deaths.”

Bennett is also still waiting for answers to her questions, including about Smith’s final conversation with council housing officers, after having experienced months of anxiety about being evicted from her home of two decades. “No one has told me who spoke to her that day, or what was said,” she explained.

The nature of the tragedy that played out last August in north London seemed almost unprecedented in modern Britain.

The desperation that drives someone to self-immolation is more familiar from foreign news reports: the protests of Tibetan monks in China, of demonstrators against Soviet tanks during the Prague spring, or the Tunisian fruit seller whose suicide sparked the Arab spring.

Several people have threatened to set themselves on fire in British welfare offices in the past decade: one man is reported to have badly burned his legs. But the tragedy in Barnet House, the concrete high-rise where the council housing offices were based until recently, appears to be the only death on record.

An Observer investigation has uncovered the pressures that were building in the months before Smith’s devastating decision, and how safety nets that could have protected her in a double crisis of housing and mental health failed at the most critical moment.

It's the level of desperation that I find frightening. It's an individual tragedy but it's also an indication of harm in our society

Barry Rawlings, councillor

There is no way to untangle the web of factors that contributed to Smith’s despair. But austerity policies have been linked to tens of thousands of extra deaths and a rise in suicides, studies have found, although most are private tragedies, not public protests.

“It’s the level of desperation that I find frightening,” said Barry Rawlings, a Labour councillor in Barnet, of Smith’s death. “It’s an individual tragedy but it’s also an indication of harm in our society. It suggests there needs to be a national review of policies on housing and welfare.”

Smith arrived on that afternoon in August 2018 to speak to the council’s “statutory homelessness” team, using an internal telephone system that separated staff from petitioners.

At some point during or after that conversation, she shouted: “Don’t make me do it.” An eyewitness said: “I thought maybe she was going to attack someone.”

But the desperation was turned only against herself. A security guard rapidly extinguished the flames and Smith, who was in her fifties, was airlifted to hospital, but she died after several months in intensive care.

Despite the extremity of the protest, once she was carried away in the air ambulance, she all but vanished from the public eye.

The council ordered its employees in Barnet House not to talk about the incident to journalists, sources claimed. Police confirmed only that there had been an incident and the local paper noted simply that a woman had been taken to hospital with burn injuries.

Smith’s housing crisis began when an eviction notice arrived through the post in April 2018, warning that her landlord had started legal proceedings to remove her from her home.

She had rent arrears of more than £700, which her mother said were a result of the bedroom tax. In theory, she could have moved to a smaller home, but across London there are severe shortages of social housing.

Councils have moved tens of thousands of families out of their areas and many out of the city entirely, government figures show. Residents in Barnet said they had been left with no option but to move as far away as Leicester. Smith was not offered an alternative home by the council, her mother said, and knew her chance of finding one in Barnet was extremely low. But her life was rooted in the area. An artistic woman who loved painting and writing poetry, she kept in touch with a global network of friends and family on Facebook, followed national and international politics and regularly visited a sick relative who lived near by.

“She liked art galleries, and going on marches,” Bennett said. “Some of her poems were very long, some were political, some about love and life in general.”

Smith had also wrestled with mental health problems, including at least one suicide episode. Her problems were severe enough that she qualified for a free transport pass.

Two weeks before her death, she saw a doctor and reported suicidal thoughts, her mother said. She had also visited the surgery before the tragedy at Barnet House, to ask about a form that could have exempted her from council tax on the grounds of mental impairment, helping to balance the bills.

She said things were getting on top of her and she was finding it difficult to cope. But this was beyond anything you would expect

Marie Bennett, mother

The doctor certified Smith as healthy, however, and when she tried to speak to someone from the practice, she was turned away by the receptionist, she told her mother.

The local clinical commissioning group said it was unable to comment on individual cases. Depression was given as a partial cause of her death, along with burn injuries.

“I feel she was let down in such a cruel way really,” Bennett said. “She said things were getting on top of her and she was finding it difficult to cope. But it was beyond anything you would expect to happen in life. Sometimes I still think I’m going to wake up [and find it was a dream], then it hits me again, the full facts.”

Smith had several meetings with Barnet council as the eviction notices built up, but staff were apparently unable to provide her with reassurance that she would be able to stay in her home. A council spokesperson said it carried out a safety review after the incident, and remained “committed to working together with our partners in helping to support vulnerable people”, but declined to comment on an individual case.

Judges handing down eviction orders ask for proof that landlords have made genuine efforts to find a negotiated solution. So a housing association would normally send several letters and make home visits to a renter who faces losing their home.

Smith’s landlord, the Home Group, said it was unable to speak to her because she “chose not to continue to communicate with us” after falling into arrears, but had informed the council about her situation.

“Given her refusal to engage, we were unable to have the conversations we really wanted to have, which were to help her find a solution in line with what she could afford, given her level of housing benefit,” said Matt Forrest, Home Group’s director of operations. “Our thoughts were at the time, and remain with, our customer and her family and friends.”

It is unclear what Smith was told in the council offices, but her mother believes she felt that eviction proceedings were already under way and could not be stopped.

“I believe she thought they were going to repossess her home,” Bennett said. “That’s the reason it was too much.”

• Names of mother and daughter have been changed to protect family privacy.

In the UK, Samaritans can be contacted by phoning 116 123 or by email to jo@samaritans.org. In the US, the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline is 1-800-273-8255. In Australia, the crisis support service Lifeline is 13 11 14. Other international helplines can be found at www.befrienders.org.
